intro: Mesosetum cardonum, commonly known as the cardon grass, is a perennial grass native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its tufted growth habit and narrow, grass-like leaves that are adapted to withstand drought conditions. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets, typical of the grass family Poaceae. Its root system is deep and extensive, allowing it to access water from deeper soil layers. Mesosetum cardonum plays a role in stabilizing soils in desert environments and is sometimes used in restoration projects.
